circuit.description: Find the resistance that gives exactly 0.03A at 6V
circuit.proof: I = V/R → R = V/I = 6/0.03 = 200Ω. So resistance must be 200Ω.

circuit.description: Make power dissipation less than 0.5W with voltage at 12V
circuit.proof: P = V²/R. For P < 0.5W: R > 12²/0.5 = 288Ω. Use R ≥ 290Ω.

circuit.description: Set brightness to exactly 50% using only resistance

titration.proof: pH = 7.0 occurs at the equivalence point, when baseVolume ≈ 25mL.

titration.description: Reach pH 4.5 without overshooting past pH 5.0
titration.proof: pH 4.5 occurs around 15mL base. The sigmoid curve is gentle here — precise control is easier.

titration.description: Find the volume where pH changes fastest
titration.proof: The steepest part of the titration curve is at the equivalence point: 25mL, where dpH/dV is maximum.

enzyme.description: Find the temperature that gives maximum reaction rate
enzyme.proof: Enzyme activity peaks at 37°C (body temperature). The Gaussian curve Vmax = 10·exp(-0.01·(T-37)²) peaks at T=37.

enzyme.description: Achieve reaction rate of exactly 5.0 μM/s
Find the substrate concentration where rate is exactly half of Vmax
enzyme.proof: Half-Vmax occurs at [S] = Km = 2.5 mmol/L. This is the Michaelis constant.

Make the pendulum complete 10 swings in 14 seconds

gravity.description: Find the distance where gravitational force equals 50N
gravity.proof: F = G·M₁·M₂/r². Adjust distance until the force reading shows ~50N.

gravity.description: Double the gravitational force by changing only planet mass
gravity.proof: F ∝ M. If initial F = 98N at M=100Me, then F = 196N at M=200Me.

gravity.description: Find the distance where orbital velocity equals 5 km/s
gravity.proof: v = √(GM/r). Adjust distance until orbital velocity shows ~5 km/s.
